page.title: 20Coddenham Interesting Houses
page.content: In Coddenham High St, the second of a pair of large oak framed structures dating fromthe late 15th century, was the "Live and Let Live" Inn, later converted to a private house with the Post Office at one end and outstanding for broad geometrical pargetting of the 17th Century. After passing a few old cottages, there is an old plastered and painted Inn. Opposite the Inn and along the road are closely built cottages with painted plastered walls. Towards the Church is a very old timbered house associated once with a religious order of Cistercian or White Nuns. Next, a lively village house of the Georgian or Regency period. Opposite is the remaining wing of an attractive Tudor house. Lastly 4 plastered cottages made into residences in the mid 1800's from what is said to have been an old Maltings.
